http.title: NinjaX - The Next Evolution of Mobile Cryptocurrency
http.html:
• NinjaX Project
  • CEO
  • Roadmap
  • WhitePaper
Select Page

The First Privacy 5.0 Cryptocurrency with Exclusive Smartphone Mining

Executive Summary
WhitePaper-EN
WhitePaper
Join Us on Telegram
WhitePaper-KR
 

Success!

Subscribe

Introducing NinjaX

 

What is NinjaX?

NinjaX is the world’s first complete mobile cryptocurrency. Private micro-payment solution combined with exclusive smartphone only mining.

A peer-to-peer mobile payment solution for businesses and individuals.

A cryptocurrency that is exclusively mined by smartphones.

True decentralization away from financial institutions and mining farms.

100% private transactions with future proof technology.

Problems with Modern Cryptocurrencies

There are two real problems with just about every cryptocurrency on the market: privacy and centralization caused by mining farms. The use of Tor, coin mixers, trusted setups, and basic anonymous addresses simply don’t work anymore when it comes to privacy. Meanwhile, mining farms are bringing centralization back into cryptocurrency by putting the blockchain’s public ledgers at risk with the amount of hash rate one group controls.

NinjaX Solution with Privacy 5.0 Technology

NinjaX solves the problem of privacy by using the NinjaX Protocol. With the tap of your finger on your smartphone, you can trade in your current NinjaX coin and have it replaced with a completely new coin that does not have any transaction history.

For this, NinjaX uses a unique variation of “Zero-Knowledge Proof Cryptography” based on the Zerocoin paper which is one of the most highly regarded papers on cryptocurrency privacy in recent years.

The NinjaX Protocol provides proof that you are exchanging a “used” coin for a “new” coin, but does not disclose the exact coin you exchanged nor is there any previous data associated with the new coin.

Providing 100% private transactions.

NinjaX Solution with Exclusive Smartphone Only Mining Technology

NinjaX solves the problem of centralization caused by mining farms with its exclusive smartphone only mining technology.

Giant mining farms are now billion dollar corporations that have centralized Bitcoin and many other cryptocurrencies on a level never imagined.

Currently, it is estimated that 60 to 80 percent of the world’s cryptocurrency hash rate is controlled by only a few mining corporations.

Besides being the opposite of cryptocurrency philosophy, when this much of the hash rate is controlled by a select few, all your coins are at risk of manipulation on the public ledgers.

This kind of centralization caused by mining farms is creating a very real problem.

Our exclusive technology makes mining of NinjaX only available with a smartphone–returning cryptocurrency mining to the individual and away from these billion dollar corporations. Our technology makes it impossible for mining farms to participate.

From any country in the world, simply open the NinjaX app, and your phone will begin to mine at an unprecedented rate with our mobile mining technology.

This is true decentralization on a level never before seen.

Benefits of Mobile Mining

    Cryptocurrency mining that is easily adopted worldwide:

  • There are currently 2.2 billion people in the world with a smartphone.
  • 99% of new smartphones are powered by Android or IOS.
  • In under one minute, anyone in the world with a smartphone and internet connection will be able to install and start mining NinjaX.

Benefits of Mobile Mining

    Cryptocurrency mining that is easily adopted worldwide:

  • There are currently 2.2 billion people in the world with a smartphone.
  • 99% of new smartphones are powered by Android or IOS.
  • In under one minute, anyone in the world with a smartphone and internet connection will be able to install and start mining NinjaX.

NinjaX Synergy of Technologies

As we present for NinjaX, we are often asked: “Why not create a privacy payment solution or just a mobile mining cryptocurrency? Why do both?”

Our answer to this is simple, We wanted to create a cryptocurrency that we ourselves would use every day.

Nearly everyone you meet will have a smartphone on them at all times. We live in a mobile world and that is not going to change.

Mobile is the future.

You can not have a truly private cryptocurrency without true decentralization. When you combine the power of mobile and blockchain technology, you have limitless opportunities.

These technologies belong together; and together they create the perfect synergy for NinjaX.

NinjaX Synergy of Technologies

As we present for NinjaX, we are often asked: “Why not create a privacy payment solution or just a mobile mining cryptocurrency? Why do both?”

Our answer to this is simple, We wanted to create a cryptocurrency that we ourselves would use every day.

Nearly everyone you meet will have a smartphone on them at all times. We live in a mobile world and that is not going to change.

Mobile is the future.

You can not have a truly private cryptocurrency without true decentralization. When you combine the power of mobile and blockchain technology, you have limitless opportunities.

These technologies belong together; and together they create the perfect synergy for NinjaX.

NinjaX CEO

Being a long time entrepreneur and martial artist, Mr. Kooistra’s professional journey began over 10 years ago. In 2008, he was awarded salesman of the year by one of the top sales industries in the United States. Since then, he has created and managed multiple businesses ranging from international commerce to foreign currency exchange trading education. In 2017 he co-founded NinjaX.

Kevin

CEO, Founder
Portland State University
Small Business Startup
Blockchain Enthusiast
Professional Currency Trader

Roadmap

2017

Q3

  • ZeroX Protocol project was created
2018

Q1

  • ZeroX Protocol is renamed: NinjaX
  • Launch of Website
  • Whitepaper Released

Q2 & Q3

  • Private Sale Begins
  • Pre and Pubic Crowdsale Opens

Q3 & Q4

  • Alpha version of NinjaX is released
  • Beta version is released to contributors
  • NinjaX app is available for IOS and Android users in USA (Q4)
2019

Q1

  • Worldwide release for IOS and Android

CVE-2018-12895.summary: WordPress through 4.9.6 allows Author users to execute arbitrary code by leveraging directory traversal in the wp-admin/post.php thumb parameter, which is passed to the PHP unlink function and can delete the wp-config.php file. This is related to missing filename validation in the wp-includes/post.php wp_delete_attachment function. The attacker must have capabilities for files and posts that are normally available only to the Author, Editor, and Administrator roles. The attack methodology is to delete wp-config.php and then launch a new installation process to increase the attacker's privileges.

CVE-2019-8942.summary: WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1 allows remote code execution because an _wp_attached_file Post Meta entry can be changed to an arbitrary string, such as one ending with a .jpg?file.php substring. An attacker with author privileges can execute arbitrary code by uploading a crafted image containing PHP code in the Exif metadata. Exploitation can leverage CVE-2019-8943.

CVE-2018-20148.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, contributors could conduct PHP object injection attacks via crafted metadata in a wp.getMediaItem XMLRPC call. This is caused by mishandling of serialized data at phar:// URLs in the wp_get_attachment_thumb_file function in wp-includes/post.php.

CVE-2018-20149.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, when the Apache HTTP Server is used, authors could upload crafted files that bypass intended MIME type restrictions, leading to XSS, as demonstrated by a .jpg file without JPEG data.

CVE-2018-20150.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, crafted URLs could trigger XSS for certain use cases involving plugins.

CVE-2018-20151.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, the user-activation page could be read by a search engine's web crawler if an unusual configuration were chosen. The search engine could then index and display a user's e-mail address and (rarely) the password that was generated by default.

CVE-2018-10101.summary: Before WordPress 4.9.5, the URL validator assumed URLs with the hostname localhost were on the same host as the WordPress server.

CVE-2018-20153.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, contributors could modify new comments made by users with greater privileges, possibly causing XSS.

CVE-2018-20152.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, authors could bypass intended restrictions on post types via crafted input.

CVE-2018-20147.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, authors could modify metadata to bypass intended restrictions on deleting files.
